Graphical abstract Carbon-fueled solid oxide fuel cells (CF-SOFCs) can electrochemically convert the chemical energy in carbon into electricity, which demonstrate both superior electrical efficiency and fuel utilisation compared to all other types of fuel cells. However, using solid carbon as the fuel of SOFCs also faces some challenges, the fluid mobility and reactive activity of carbon-based fuels are much lower than those of gaseous fuels. Therefore, the anode reaction kinetics plays a crucial role in determining the electrochemical performance of CF-SOFCs. Herein, the progress of various anodes in CF-SOFCs is reviewed from the perspective of material compositions, electrochemical performance and microstructures. Challenges faced in developing high performance anodes for CF-SOFCs are also discussed. Keywords Carbon Anodes Solid oxide fuel cells Energy conversion Reaction processes 1 Introduction As the main component of coal and biomass, carbon is an energy carrier vital to human society. Carbon-based fuel is still the dominating energy source with sufficient reliability and competitiveness due to its high volumetric energy density, low price and rich reserves [1]. However, the coal utilization technologies should be improved because of the characteristics of the current coal thermal power generation, including relatively considerable pollutant gas emissions, low efficiencies, and heavy metal pollution. Therefore, it is imperative to develop more effective technologies of converting these solid carbon fuels into more useful forms of energy. Direct carbon fuel cell (DCFC) is a newly developed technology and has demonstrated its attractive prospects [2–4]. DCFC can directly use solid carbon as the fuel to achieve efficient energy conversion through electrochemical methods. Various types of carbon sources can be applied to the DCFC system, including petroleum coke, PMDF, graphite, activated carbon, coal coke, biomass carbon, pyrolyzed hydrocarbons or even organic waste [5–9]. In addition, the DCFCs can use a certain volume of fuel more efficiently, because of the high fuel energy density of the solid carbon [10,11]. The overall reaction of DCFC system can be described as Eq. (1): (1) C ( s ) + O 2 ( g ) → C O 2 ( g ) The practical efficiency of DCFCs can reach up to 80%, which is a significantly improvement compared to the traditional coal-based thermal power plants (usually less than 40%) [12,13]. Therefore, DCFCs demonstrate the promising application in the efficient and environmentally friendly conversion of carbon-based fuel. Since the first generation of carbon fuel cell was manufactured by Jacques in the 19th century, the topic of DCFCs is getting an increasing attention. Much work has been done to develop fuel cells fueled by carbon fuel with acceptable electrochemical performance [14]. Historically, depending on the different types of electrolyte applied, DCFCs can be divided into different types, such as molten hydroxide (MHFC), molten carbonate (MCFC) and solid oxide (SOFC) [5,13,15]. The application of molten electrolyte in DCFC (MHFC and MCFC) is due to the advantage that it can expand the operational regime of solid carbon, which makes it easier for carbon fuel to participate in the anode reactions due to the extended active reaction area [16–19]. However, these types of DCFC suffer from the primary obstacle that the molten electrolyte will corrode the electrodes and metal current collector. Therefore, among these different types of DCFCs, DCFCs with solid electrolyte, which are also known as the carbon-fueled solid oxide fuel cells (CF-SOFC), are believed to be the most promising due to their easy construction and high mechanical strength, and most of the researches in recent years have focused on the CF-SOFCs [20,21]. Therefore, CF-SOFCs are more suitable for carbon fuels utilization for power generation. Traditional solid oxide ion conductors, such as yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) and La0.9Sr0.1Ga0.8Mg0.2O3− δ (LSGM), are widely used as electrolytes in CF-SOFCs. Unfortunately, despite considerable attention has been paid to CF-SOFCs, this technology is still at a relatively early stage of development and will require a lot of effort to meet the requirements of commercialization. One of the major problems hindering the development of CF-SOFCs is the sluggish anode reactions kinetics, which is due to the much lower reactive activity and fluid mobility of solid carbon than those of gaseous fuels. Not as the common gaseous fuel, which can be easily delivered through the porous electrode structure to reach the triple-phase boundaries (TPBs) for its electrochemical oxidation with oxygen ions migrating from electrolyte, it’s difficult to transport the solid carbon fuel into the reactive area. Therefore, the properties of anode materials and carbon fuels and the contact between them have a strong effect on the electrochemical performance of CF-SOFCs [22,23]. There is no doubt that there’re also some other challenges, such as the optimisation of the operational system, the processing of solid carbon fuels, exploring the carbon electrochemical reaction kinetics and mechanism [4,24–27]. In this paper, particular attention is given to the anode materials and microstructure involved in CF-SOFCs, because that the anode reaction kinetics plays a crucial role in determining the electrochemical performance of CF-SOFCs. In a CF-SOFC power system, there are many important performance parameters, such as the power density, open circuit voltage, lifetime and efficiency, which are crucial to measure the possibility of the CF-SOFC in practical applications. For example, the power density of CF-SOFC greatly affects the size, cost and portability of the system. The catalytic activity, stability, and catalytic mechanism of the anode will directly affect these performance indicators of CF-SOFC. Herein, various material compositions and microstructural designs for CF-SOFC anodes in recent years are reviewed in brief, the anode materials and reaction characteristics of different CF-SOFC systems are summarized, as shown in Fig. 1 . Moreover, the challenges faced in developing high-performance anodes for CF-SOFC are also discussed. 2 Development of materials and microstructures of CF-SOFCs anodes 2.1 Molten metals anode For the cermet anode that commonly used in SOFCs fuelled by gaseous fuels, when applied in a CF-SOFC system, the limited solid–solid contacts lead to sluggish anode kinetics. The molten metal anode provides the possibility to solve this problem, which exhibits high conductivity and extended active reaction area. Historically, the liquid tin with low-melting-point was the first metal anode studied as a candidate for CF-SOFCs [28,29]. The calculated Nernst potential corresponding to reaction between Sn and O2 is 0.93 V at 700 °C. Therefore, if the operating voltage of a CF-SOFC is lower than this threshold, the electrochemical reaction between Sn and O2− will occur. However, the major issue for the liquid Sn anode is that a solid SnO2 layer will form at the anode/electrolyte interface during the operation, which is insulating and has a high melting point (1630 °C); the SnO2 layer will inhibit the further transfer of the O2− from the anode-electrolyte interface, which will led to an increasing ohmic resistance [30]. Cao et al. [31] introduced Li-K carbonate to alleviate the problems caused by the formation of SnO2. Sn mixed with different proportions of carbonate was fabricated to improve reaction activity. The contact between the liquid Sn anode and the solid oxide electrolyte can be effectively improved due to the introduction of molten Li-K carbonate, and the ohmic impedance (R Ω) of the single cell is also reduced. The Sn can also be oxidized at the Sn-molten carbonate interface due to the high ionic conductivity of carbonate, and the generated SnO2 can be transported into the bulk of anode more easily, as shown in Fig. 2 . Besides the liquid Sn anode, the potential of using Ag, In, Pb, Bi and Fe for CF-SOFCs has also been studied [32,33]. Applying molten Sb as the anode of CF-SOFCs has attracted more and more attention in recent years due to its unique advantages. The melting point of antimony oxide (Sb2O3) is much lower than that of SnO2, which is only 656 °C; In addition, there is a density difference between Sb and Sb2O3, so the generated Sb2O3 at the anode/electrolyte interface will lead to a hierarchical structure of Sb and Sb2O3. Therefore, the lighter liquid Sb2O3 layer will move continuously during the cell operation instead of forming a solid layer with increasing thickness, which improves the anode reactions activity. Jayakumar et al. studied the electrochemical performance of CF-SOFC with molten Sb anode [34]. The anode reactions can be described as follows: (2) 2 S b + 3 O 2 - → S b 2 O 3 + 6 e - (3) S b 2 O 3 + 2 / 3 C → 2 S b + 3 / 2 C O 2 The Nernst potential for Reaction (2), relative to air, is 0.75 V at 700 °C [32]. The molten Sb anode actually acts as a fuel, which will be oxidized at the anode/electrolyte interface, with the generating Sb2O3 being reduced by the solid carbon fuel in another separate step. The gradually formed hierarchical structure of Sb layer and Sb2O3 layer is shown in Fig. 3 (a). The CF-SOFC with molten Sb anode achieves a maximum power density (MPD) of 360 mW cm−2 and a totally impedance of 0.37 Ω cm2 at 700 °C (Fig. 3(b and c)). Based on the molten Sb anode, alloying Sb with another high-density metal is an effective strategy to enhance the fluidity inside the anode. Therefore, adding Ag into Sb is an effective modification strategy, which will increase the density of metal phase to some extent, and the alloy also has a lower melting point. It should be noted that silver oxide will decompose to silver at the high operating temperature of CF-SOFCs, so Ag would keep staying in metal phase, which means that the OCV of the cell with Ag-Sb anode is still associated at equilibrium between Sb and Sb2O3 (0.75 V at 700 °C). Duan et al. [35] studied the Sb1− x -Ag x (x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3) alloy as anode for tubular YSZ-supported CF-SOFCs. The output performance of the single cells with Sb1− x -Ag x anodes is close to that of the cell with Sb anode. It’s reported that, during the operation, the initially uniformly distributed Sb-Ag alloy melt will be gradually replaced by a gradient distribution of Ag concentration, as shown in Fig. 4 . In an ideal molten anode CF-SOFC system, both the metal anodes and the corresponding metal oxides should have low melting points, so that the cell can be operated at an acceptable temperature. The density difference between the metals and metal oxides (Metals have a higher density) is also important to promote the reactions in anode chamber. However, few metal materials can meet these requirements in the medium temperature range (600–800 °C), the candidate materials that have been studied are summarized in Table 1 , only the metal Sb anode has achieved an acceptable output power density at 700 °C. The OCV of molten metal anode CF-SOFC is based on the equilibrium between the metals and their oxides [32], which is relatively low, only 0.75 V to single cells with molten Sb anode at 700 °C, and leads to a decrease in theoretical efficiency. The stability of the electrolyte is another issue to be considered in this type of CF-SOFCs. Scandium-stabilized zirconia (ScSZ) has been applied as the electrolyte in these CF-SOFCs, however, it will suffer severe corrosion at high currents. YSZ electrolyte exhibits good stability in CF-SOFCs with molten anode, but its ionic conductivities are far lower than those of ScSZ, so it will limit the electrochemical performance of an electrolyte-supported CF-SOFC [36]. 2.2 Anode for direct carbon solid oxide fuel cells Direct carbon solid oxide fuel cell (DC-SOFC) has an all-solid-state cell structure, so in this case, the contact between the solid carbon and the anode is limited, which makes it difficult for carbon to participate in direct electrochemical oxidation. However, at the high operating temperature of DC-SOFCs (usually above 700 °C), the reverse Boudouard reaction (RBR) is thermodynamically favourable, as described in Eq. (4), so the equilibrium gas composition of carbon–oxygen system is dominated by CO, which can diffuse into the anode skeleton for electrochemical oxidation. Therefore, the electrochemical oxidation of CO makes a major contribution to the output of DC-SOFCs, as described in Eq. (5). (4) C O 2 + C → 2 C O (5) C O + O 2 - → C O 2 + 2 e - The most common used Ni-based and Ag-based materials in SOFCs, such as Ni-YSZ and Ag-GDC, have also been studied as anodes of DC-SOFCs [38–40], since they are active in catalyzing the electrochemical oxidation of CO. The basic requirements for the solid anode materials of DC-SOFCs are similar to those for SOFCs with gaseous fuels, including high electronic and ionic conductivity, strong catalytic activity, chemical stability, suitable porosity, robust mechanical strength, thermal compatibility and easy fabrication [41]. In addition to the Ni-based and Ag-based composite anodes, some other solid oxide anodes with different compositions and structures have also been studied in recent years. 2.2.1 Anode for unmodified carbon fuel The electrochemical performance of the DC-SOFC anodes fuelled by pure carbon fuel is usually limited by the activity of the reverse Boudouard reaction (RBR), which will further affect the electrochemical oxidation of CO. Liu et al. [6] presented an anode-supported tubular SOFC with Ni-YSZ as the anode. Carbon black was used as the fuel, and the cell achieved an acceptable output performance with the MPDs of 104, 75, and 47mWcm−2 at 850, 800 and 750 °C, respectively, using N2 as the fluidizing gas. Applying CO2 as the fluidizing gas is an effective way to improve the electrochemical performance of DC-SOFCs [42], which can promote RBR at high temperatures [43]. Kaklidis et al. demonstrated the advantage of using CO2 as the fluidizing gas [44]. A DC-SOFC with the configuration of Co–CeO2/YSZ/Ag was fabricated with lignite as the fuel. The MPD of ~10mWcm−2 at 800 °C was achieved with 20wt% Co/CeO2 as the anode and CO2 as the fluidizing gas. Kulkarni et al. [45] presented a 20-mol% yttria-doped ceria (YDC) infiltrated with Ni as an anode of a DC-SOFC. The single cell achieved a MPD of 40 mW cm−2 at 800 °C with CO2/N2 mixture as the fluidizing gas. In addition to using CO2 as a fluidizing gas, the presence of some metal oxidation can also promote the RBR and thus improve the performance of DC-SOFCs. Therefore, the impurities in raw coal fuels, such as some mineral ash (like Fe2O3 and CaO), will have a positive effect on the anode reactions [46,47]. By this means, Wu et al. [3] used Ag-Gd0.1Ce0.9O2− δ (Ag-GDC) as symmetrical electrodes of a DC-SOFC with brown coal as the fuel. The cell achieved a MPD of 221 mW cm−2 at 850 °C. In addition, a stable discharge process (for about 13.7 h) with the fuel utilization of 61.5% was also demonstrated when the single cell was operated under a constant current of 0.1 A. Qiu et al. [48] also demonstrated the use of Ag-GDC anode with carbon-rich biochar as the fuel. The naturally grown alkaline earth metal elements in the chars, such as K, Ca, and Mg, can serve as the RBR catalyst to improve the anode reactions. The cell achieved a MPD of 260 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. Mixed ionic and electronic conducting materials (MIECs) are also widely used in SOFCs, because they can efficiently extend the anode reaction zone and promote the direct electrochemical processes on the surface of the electrode [49]. In addition, some MIECs are also effective sulfur tolerant materials, which provides development prospects for the application of sulfur-containing coal in DCFCs [50–53]. Therefore, this kind of materials shows application prospects in DC-SOFCs. The La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3− δ (LSCF) exhibits high mixed ionic and electronic conductivities in air and is therefore chosen as the first-generation anode material, which achieves good catalytic performance in gaseous hydrocarbon fuel cells [54,55]. Kulkarni et al. [49] used LSCF as both the anode and cathode in a DC-SOFC, and a MPD of 50 mW cm−2 was generated at 804 °C in a single cell using solid carbon as the fuel. The LSCF electrode material was also evaluated in electrolyte-supported tubular DC-SOFC which achieved the MPD of ~ 25mW cm−2 at 820 °C with He as the fluidizing gas. However, the use of a LSCF anode has two main disadvantages, one is the low electronic conductivity in a reducing atmosphere which leads to poor current collection efficiency, and the other is the poor phase structure stability of LSCF in reducing conditions [49]. Ali et al. [56] investigated LiNiCuZnFeO (LNCZFO) as a potential anode of DC-SOFCs. The electrochemical performance of DC-SOFCs fuelled by three types of carbon fuels (bituminous, sub-bituminous, lignite) was studied, and the cell delivered the highest MPD of 58 mW cm−2 at 700 °C with subbituminous as the fuel. It can be concluded that the carbon fuels with high carbon content, low sulfur and ash content is favorable for achieving higher output performance. Li et al. [57] developed La0.8Sr0.2Fe0.9Nb0.1O3− δ (LSFNb) as a novel anode material for DC-SOFCs. The electrolyte-supported cells with LSFNb anode demonstrated the MPDs of 302.8 and 218.5 mW cm−2 at 850 °C, when activated carbon and corn straw carbon were used as the fuels, respectively. The cell with activated carbon as the fuel achieved higher output performance which proves that particle size, specific surface area and porosity of carbon fuels have a great influence on the anode reactions. Titanates are also chosen as anodes for the DC-SOFCs because of their excellent phase structure stability in reducing conditions and good sulfur resistance. Kulkarni et al. [58] studied the catalytic activity of Co doped La0.3Sr0.7Ti0.93Co0.07O3 (LSCT) and La0.3Sr0.7TiO3 (LST) as anodes of DC-SOFCs. The single cells generated the MPDs of 6 mW cm−2 and 25 mW cm−2 when using LST and LSCT as the anodes, respectively. However, the output performance of DC-SOFCs with this type of anodes is far lower than those with a Ni-based anode, which is mainly due to the poor catalytic activity and ionic conductivity of titanates. 2.2.2 Anode for deposited carbon The DC-SOFCs with deposited carbon as the fuel are also known as the pyrolytic carbon air fuel cells (P-CAFCs), which were first developed by Ihara et al. [59] In a P-CAFC system, pyrolytic carbon that deposited onto the surface of anode acts as the fuel and participates in the electrochemical oxidation process to generate power. Normally, the pyrolytic carbon comes from the thermal decomposition of some small aliphatic hydrocarbon molecules, such as CH4 and C3H8, which are first introduced into the anode chamber [59,60]. A major advantage of this system is that the gaseous hydrocarbon precursors can penetrate deep into the porous anode skeleton and the deposit carbon contacts the anode better than direct filling of solid carbon, thus improving the diffusion problem of carbon fuel and facilitating the electrochemical oxidation of carbon [61]. Hasegawa et al. [62] developed a DC-SOFC with Ni-GDC anode that delivered a MPD of 55 mW cm−2 at 900 °C with deposit carbon as the fuel. The possible reaction mechanism of the deposit carbon fuelled DC-SOFC on the Ni-based anode side is shown in Fig. 5 , the main electrochemical reactions occur at the TPBs. The most common used anode in a DC-SOFC with deposit carbon fuel is Ni-based cermet materials, because Ni is highly active in catalyzing the cracking of alkanes and the composite ceramic materials, such as YSZ and GDC, can provide ionic conductivity. Li et al. [63,64] found that most of pyrolytic carbon was deposited on the surface of Ni particles and only a small part was on the surface of YSZ when a Ni-YSZ anode was used in a DC-SOFC. The characterization of Raman and XPS spectra revealed that the deposited carbon was generated by cracking CH4 over the surface of the Ni-YSZ anode at high temperature, which mainly contained graphite and amorphous carbon. However, during the cell operation, the electrochemical oxidation of the deposited carbon is most difficult to proceed on the Ni particles, easier on the YSZ particle surfaces and easiest at the three-phase boundary (TPB), which means that not all the carbon deposited on the anode surface will participate in the electrochemical reactions. A stepwise mechanism for the direct carbon electrochemical reactions is also given as follows. (The CRS used in the formulas denotes the reactive C atom at the interface, and the OX O and V’’ O denote the O2− and oxygen vacancy in YSZ, respectively) (6) O 2 - p r o d u c t i o n : O O X → O 2 - + V O ' ' (7) F i r s t O 2 - a d s o r p t i o n : C R S + O 2 - → C R S O 2 - (8) F a s t d i s c h a r g e : C R S O 2 - → C R S O - + e - (9) F a s t d i s c h a r g e : C R S O - → C R S O + e - (10) C O d e s o r p t i o n : C R S O → C O ( g ) (11) S e c o n d O 2 - a d s o r p t i o n : C R S O + O 2 - → C R S O 2 2 - (12) F a s t d i s c h a r g e : C R S O 2 2 - → C R S O 2 - + e - Fast discharge and CO2 desorption: (13) C R S O 2 - → C R S O 2 ( g ) + e - T o t a l r e a c t i o n : C R S + O 2 - → C O + 2 e - (14) C R S + 2 O 2 - → C O 2 + 4 e - However, although the use of deposited carbon as a fuel effectively improves the contact between anode and fuel, the kinetics of anode reactions is still sluggish, and the activation polarization resistance of the direct electrochemical oxidation of carbon is still high. In addition, preparation of carbon fuels by alkane cracking reduces fuel utilization efficiency, because the hydrogen produced at the same time is released and wasted. Furthermore, the total achievable output power of the DC-SOFCs with deposited carbon as the fuel is also limited by the fuel supply, because the amount of carbon that can be deposited is limited, and the anode materials that have the activity to catalyze the cracking of alkanes to deposit carbon, such as Ni, are often difficult to catalyze the direct electrochemical oxidation of carbon alone. 2.2.3 Anode for catalyst-loaded carbon fuel As it’s hard for the solid carbon fuels to transport to the reactive area through porous anode framework, boosting the reverse Boudouard reaction (RBR) can be an efficient way to improve the performance of DC-SOFCs, because the generated CO from RBR can be electrochemically oxidized at TPBs. The CO2 produced by the oxidation of CO can continue to participate in the RBR, so these two reciprocal coupling reactions are the key anode reactions that determine the output performance of DC-SOFCs. Adding RBR catalyst to the carbon fuel can effectively improve the electrochemical performance of DC-SOFCs by this way. It has been proved that some alkali metal salts and metal are highly active catalysts for RBR [65–68], which have been used to modify the carbon fuels. Xie et al. [69] fabricated an anode-supported tubular SOFC with Cu–CeO2–YSZ composite anode. The cell was tested with 5 wt% Fe-loaded activated carbon as the fuel, and delivered a MPD of ~ 135 mW cm−2 at 850 °C. In addition, the cell was also test with CO as the fuel, which achieved almost the same MPD and open circuit voltage (OCV) as the DC-SOFC. These evidences suggest that the dominating anode reaction process of the DC-SOFC with Fe-loaded carbon fuel is very similar to that in a SOFC operated with pure CO. Therefore, it’s the electrochemical oxidation of CO that dominates the output power of DC-SOFCs with catalyst-loaded carbon as the fuel. Unfortunately, the DC-SOFC with this Cu–CeO2–YSZ anode exhibited a poor stability, the voltage of the cell operated on carbon dropped to zero within 3 h during the stability test at 850 °C. Cai et al. [70] developed Ag–GDC as both of anode and cathode for DC-SOFCs. With Fe-loaded activated carbon as the fuel, the cell achieved a MPD of 212 mW cm−2 at 850 °C. The use of Ag-GDC anode with Ca-loaded activated carbon as the fuel was also demonstrated [47], the single cell powered by 5 wt% Ca-loaded activated carbon achieved the MPD of 373 mW cm−2 at 850 °C, which was much higher than that of the cell with pure carbon as the fuel (258 mW cm−2). Yu et al. [71] presented that adding a small amount of Fe into the Ni-based anode could improve the electrochemical performance of a DC-SOFC. The Ni1− x Fe x O δ (x = 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3)-YSZ anode-supported cell with Fe-loaded activated carbon as the fuel delivered the highest MPD of 529 mW cm−2 at 800 °C, when the composition is × = 0.1. The single cell also exhibited a stable output at a constant current density of 0.1 A cm−2 for 15 h at 800 °C. Yang et al. [72] developed a novel Ni-YSZ anode-supported tubular DC-SOFC integrated with a ceramic CO2-permeable membrane, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). Carbon fuel modified with a RBR catalyst was used as the fuel of the cell. The CO2-permeable membrane composed of a CO2 − 3 mixture and an O2− conducting phase (Sm0.2Ce0.8O1.9, SDC) was fabricated for the separation of CO2, the film restrained all the gases in the anode chamber except CO2, so that the CO generated from RBR can participate in the electrochemical oxidation reaction more efficiently. Therefore, a high MPD of 279.3 mW cm−2, at 850 °C, was achieved for the DC-SOFC, the I-P-V curves and EIS data are shown in Fig. 6(b and c). A small DC-SOFC stack composed of two batteries was also fabricated, which could run continuously for 200 min. Inspired by the advantages of molten anodes, Ju et al. [73] used liquid Sn to modify carbon black as the fuel of DC-SOFCs. Compared with the unmodified fuel, mixing carbon fuels with Sn improved the output performance and the single cell with Ni-YSZ anode achieved a MPD of 60.5 mW cm−2 at 900 °C. The molten Sn can build a favorable bridge between the solid fuel and anode and thus improve the reactivity of carbon. 2.3 Anode for hybrid direct carbon fuel cells As aforementioned, it’s hard for solid carbon particles to be transported into the anode skeleton, so the limited electrochemical active sites remain a major obstacle to improve the CF-SOFCs output performance. Therefore, introducing a molten medium into the carbon fuel has been studied to improve solid-phase contact at the anode side. This strategy was first proposed by Peelen et al. [74], in which molten carbonate was used in the anode to promote carbon conversion. It has been demonstrated previously that the molten carbonate has the capability to promote electrochemical reactions of carbon and enhance the output performance of fuel cells. The enhanced liquid-to-solid contact between carbon fuel and molten carbonate makes it easier for charge transport. This kind of CF-SOFCs is also known as the hybrid direct carbon fuel cells (HDCFCs) [75]. The HDCFCs technology can be considered as a combination of molten carbonate fuel cells (MCFCs) and SOFCs, which combine the advantages of these two types of fuel cells and effectively improve the overall performance. The addition of carbonate improves the performance of HDCFC, but also complicates the reactions on the anode side. Jain et al. [10] proposed that the CO3 2− would also act as a reactive ion for carbon oxidation, carbon can be completely oxidized or partially oxidized by carbonate, as shown below: (15) C + 2 C O 3 2 - → 3 C O 2 + 4 e - (16) C + C O 3 2 - → C O + C O 2 + 2 e - In addition, a combination of CO2 and O2– will regenerate CO3 2–, as described as follow: (17) C O 2 + O 2 - → C O 3 2 - A more detailed carbon reaction mechanism based on the HDCFCs system was proposed by Li et al. [21] The catalytic effects of carbonates in promoting cell performance were summarized as a modified oxygen-reduction cycle mechanism. In this configuration, Ni-YSZ was used as the anode with sieved and pyrolyzed sawdust as the fuels in CO2 or N2 flowing. When the HDCFC used N2 as a fluidizing gas, the thermal dissociation of carbonate produced metal oxide (M2O), which was then further oxidized to peroxide (M2O2) or higher oxide, a plausible oxidation–reduction cycle could be described as below: (18) M 2 C O 3 + C + 2 O 2 - → M 2 O + 2 C O 2 + 4 e - (19) O r M 2 C O 3 + C + O 2 - → M 2 O + C O 2 + C O + 2 e - (20) M 2 O + n O 2 - → M 2 O 1 + n + 2 n e - (21) M 2 O 1 + n + n C → M 2 O + n C O When in a CO2 atmosphere, considering the alkali-catalyzed reactions, the thermodynamic dissociation reactions Eqs. (18) and (19) in which carbonates participate are not likely to occur due to the tough reaction of M2O to M2CO3 conversion. Therefore, a metal-oxide-metal cycle was proposed to explain the effect of alkali metal carbonates: (22) M 2 C O 3 + 2 C → 2 M + 3 C O (23) 2 M + C O 2 → M 2 O + C O (24) M 2 O + C O 2 → M 2 C O 3 It can be concluded that the Li2CO3 and K2CO3 eutectic salts can be used as a catalytic medium to promote the production of CO, and thus improve performance of HDCFCs in CO2 atmosphere. Unlike loading metal or metal oxide catalysts, the carbon fuel mixed with carbonate can directly generate CO without undergoing an electrochemical reaction at high temperature, because of the decomposition of CO3 2− and RBR. In addition, the strong catalytic effect of carbonate can accelerate the gasification of carbon, which is helpful to reduce the operational temperature of DCFCs [76]. Therefore, in the HDCFC system, CO is also an important fuel, which can participate in the electrochemical process to generate power [77,78], so the common high active Ni-based anodes exhibit good catalytic activity in HDCFC. Jiang et al. [79] demonstrated a high-performance Ni-YSZ anode-supported HDCFC. The single cell delivered a MPD of 878 mW cm−2 at 750 °C with Medium Density Fibreboard as the fuel. The achieved output performance is comparable with current commercial SOFC and significantly exceeds the performance of commercial MCFC. Liu et al. [80] evaluated Ni modified Ce0.6Mn0.3Fe0.1O2 (Ni-CMF) as the anode for HDCFC. Because of the high conductivity and good catalytic activity of Ni-CMF, the single cell showed a MPD of 580.7 mW cm−2 at 800 °C with activated carbon as the fuel. The introduction of Ni greatly improved the catalytic activity of the anode, the MPD of single cell with CMF anode was only 171.8 mW cm−2 at 800 °C, about 30% of the Ni-CMF anode. Xie et al. [81] developed Ag-infiltrated Ni-(Y2O3)0.08(ZrO2)0.92 as the anode of HDCFCs, the single cell with modified char as the fuel demonstrated a maximum power density of 403 mW cm−2 at 750 °C. However, in the HDCFCs system, the anode atmosphere becomes more corrosive because of the existence of molten carbonate, the common nickel-based anode materials suffer from the poor chemical stability because Ni and NiO will gradually dissolve into the carbonate [82]. Perovskite materials are also studied as the anodes for HDCFCs, especially the mixed ionic-electronic conductor materials, which can effectively extend the active area. Liu et al. [83] evaluated Sr2Fe1.4X0.1Mo0.5O6− δ (SFXM, X = Bi, Al and Mg) as anode materials for HDCFCs. The X doping has a significant effect on the valence distribution of B-site elements, which alters the Mo6+/Mo5+ and Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio, and thus is beneficial to improve the conductivity of the anodes. The in-situ exsolution of metallic Fe is also demonstrated to enhance the catalytic activity of anodes. All these advantages are responsible for the remarkable electrochemical performances of HDCFCs with SFXM anodes. The Bi-doped SFBM exhibited the highest conductivity and achieved optimal electrochemical performance as the anode, the single cell achieved a MPD of 399 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. As the electrochemical oxidation process of CO also makes an important contribution to the output performance of HDCFCs, Ma et al. [84] proposed a new strategy to improve the electrochemical performance of single cells by designing a novel Cu-doped (PrBa)0.95Fe1.8− x Cu x Nb0.2O5+ δ (PBFCN) as the anode materials of HDCFCs, which effectively improves the chemical adsorption and electrochemical oxidation processes of CO. The greatly enhanced adsorption activity benefits from the doping of Cu. The Cu+ ions in PBFCN are highly reactive sites, which can absorb CO to form Cu+-carbonyls species and thus promote electrochemical oxidation of CO. The CO-TPD test demonstrates that the doping of Cu improves the adsorption activity of PBFCN to CO (Fig. 7 (b)). Therefore, the single cell with PBFCu0.4N anode delivered the optimal output performance with a MPD of 431 mW cm−2 at 800 °C, and the single cell could operate stably for 35 h at 750 °C, as shown in Fig. 7(c and f). The EIS and DRT data (Fig. 7(d and e)) also show the improved gas diffusion processes due to the enhanced adsorption activity of PBFCN. Designing unique electrode architectures is considered to be effective in improving the mass transport and extending TPBs [85], which has also been applied in CF-SOFCs. Liu et al. [86] developed a novel Ce0.6Mn0.3Fe0.1O2 (CMF) hierarchically structured porous hollow nanofibers as an highly active anode for HDCFCs. The designed anode structure with large specific surface area offered abundant active sites for the electrochemical oxidation reactions and channels for mass and electron transport processes, as shown in Fig. 8 . The single cell with CMF nanofibers anode achieved a MPD of 238 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. The CMF hollow nanofibers anode was further optimized by surface infiltration of Ni. Benefiting from the strong synergistic effects between the CMF scaffold and Ni nanoparticles, the optimized HDCFC achieved an enhanced electrochemical performance with a MPD of 520.2 mW cm−2 at 800 °C. Optimizing the anode architecture also helps HDCFCs to operate at relatively low temperatures (500–600 °C). Wu et al. [87] fabricated a high-performance 3D solid-state architected anode for HDCFCs below 600 °C. A soak-and-firing method was proposed to fabricate the 3D ceramic textile Ni–GDC anode, as visually summarized in Fig. 9 (a). The NiO–GDC nanofibers were knitted together after calcination and formed a textile-like anode framework, this special structure ensured adequate porosity and also had sufficient mechanical strength. The anode was loaded with carbon-carbonate fuel. The single cell with the 3D anode achieved the MPD of 325 mW cm−2 at 600 °C with graphite as the fuel. The 3D anode framework significantly extended the active zone for the electrochemical oxidation of carbon, thus improving the output performance. The as-prepared anode framework was shown in Fig. 9(b), the bundles of hollow fibers were well combined with the electrolyte. After the carbon-carbonate fuel was loaded, the carbon fuel could effectively reach the electrolyte/electrode interfaces, as shown in Fig. 9(c). The major electrochemical reactions on the anode side of the cell was illustrated in Fig. 9(d). Considering that the characteristics of carbon fuel will affect the performance of CF-SOFCs, especially the particle size of carbon will seriously affect the active sites in contact with the electrode, so the structure design of CF-SOFC anodes should be related to the size of the carbon particles. Ma et al. [88] studied the effect of size matching between the carbon particles and anode pores on the electrochemical performance of HDCFCs. A honeycombed and size-matching (PrBa)0.95Fe1.4Cu0.4Nb0.2O5+ δ anode architecture was fabricated by water droplet templating, as shown in Fig. 10 (a and b). The active area of anodes could be maximized by using appropriate carbon particles, so the mass-transfer processes at the anodes can be effectively improved. A remarkable MPD of 765 mW cm−2 at 800 °C was achieved when using the matching carbon fuel, as shown in Fig. 10(c), which is about 57% higher than the cell fabricated by traditional screen printing. The distribution of the relaxation time (DRT) analysis (Fig. 10(d)) showed that the size matching between the anode and carbon fuel enhanced the reactivity of carbon. 3 Challenges in developing anodes CF-SOFCs exhibit a promising future because of their attractive advantages. However, there are still some challenges in developing anode to be met for the commercial application of CF-SOFC technology. First of all is the matter of long-term durability of the CF-SOFCs, which lags far behind the current gas-fueled SOFCs. The first issue of the anodes that is related to the durability is the chemical stability of the anode materials. The metal Ni in commonly used Ni-based anodes will be electrochemically oxidized into NiO at the electrolyte/anode interface, which will lead to an increase in the charge transfer resistance and the ohmic resistance [89]. Other types of anode materials, such as perovskite, may suffer phase structure damage in the reducing atmosphere on the anode side; Another issue is the deactivation of the anode materials during the CF-SOFCs operation, which mainly occurs on the molten metal anodes and anodes for carbon fuel mixed with carbonate. The molten metal anodes also suffer the generation of metal oxides during cells operation, which may have high melting points and low electrical conductivity, leading to an increase in electrochemical impedance. Molten carbonates used for HDCFCs are highly corrosive, the common anode components such as Ni and NiO will gradually dissolve into molten carbonates during the operation of HDCFCs [82,90], leading to an irreversible loss of active sites. In addition, not only the anode, the whole system of CF-SOFCs will suffer from the corrosion of these molten metal or carbonate because of their aggressive nature. Another challenge in anode preparation stems from the solid carbon fuel used. Since the particle size of solid carbon is much larger than that of gas fuels, there is limited and impermanent contact between solid carbonaceous fuels and anode during the operation of CF-SOFCs, leading to the poor output performance and stability. Therefore, the traditional porous anode framework may no longer be suitable for carbon fuels with a particle size much larger than the anode pore size. A more efficient anode structure should be fabricated to improve the reactivity of carbon and achieve an acceptable electrochemical performance. In addition, anode materials may also be sensitive to impurities in raw coal fuels, such as sulphide, PH3 and HCl [91]. Coal, as the most abundant carbon-based fuel, contains a considerable amount of sulfur which will be converted into gaseous H2S under the reducing anode atmospheres of CF-SOFCs. Ni-based anode materials will be poisoned by H2S to form NiSx compounds or adsorb H2S on the active sites of anodes [91,92], which will lead to a significant reduction in catalytic activity and conductivity of anodes, thus degrading the output performance of CF-SOFCs [93]. Therefore, most of the anode materials currently studied are applied to CF-SOFCs using high-purity carbon fuels such as graphite, carbon black, activated carbon and pre-treated carbon, which is more expensive than raw coal [94] [95] [96] Highly stable, especially sulphur tolerant anode materials with high catalytic activity to the reactions at anode side should be further studied. The development of anode materials is still challenging to be addressed for achieving high electrochemical performance, all kinds of effective catalysts could be worthy of study to improve the cell efficiency. Moreover, studies of oxygen surface exchange and diffusion, CO/CO2 adsorption and catalysis, ionic conductivity are required on the promising anode materials to improve our understanding of the electrocatalytic properties and reaction mechanism. Different CF-SOFC anode materials that have been studied are listed in Table 2 . The current anodes exhibit different catalytic advantages, as summarized in Fig. 11 , but they are not enough to achieve satisfactory electrochemical performance. Strong anode catalysts must be found for high-performance CF-SOFCs, which need to meet the requirements of stability, efficiency and catalytic activity, so that the dependence of high-performance cells on additives (carbonate, alkali metal, etc.) in carbon fuel can be reduced, which can not only reduce costs, but also increase the lifetime of CF-SOFCs. 4 Conclusions and perspectives CF-SOFC is considered as a promising electrochemical technology that can directly convert chemical energy stored in carbon fuels into electric energy in an eco-friendly and efficient manner. However, compared with gas-fueled SOFCs, CF-SOFCs are still in the early stage of development. The poor electrochemical performance of CF-SOFC is mainly limited by the low activity of anode reactions caused by the use of solid carbon fuels. The development of anodes with high stability and catalytic activity is crucial to the practical application of CF-SOFCs. Many types of anodes have been studied so far, but the low power densities and poor durability are still common issues that have not been completely solved. Applying molten anode and adding additives (carbonate, alkali metal, etc.) into the carbon fuel are efficient strategies to achieve relatively higher power densities, but they suffer from the poor stability. Optimizing the anode structure to improve the mass transfer processes, designing new materials with high catalytic activity for the anode reactions and achieving stable power output should be comprehensively considered to promote the development of CF-SOFCs. Thus, considerable work is still required to further develop high-performance materials and optimize microstructure for the anodes of CF-SOFCs, there is still a long way before CF-SOFCs can be applied on an industrial scale. coredata.dc:description: Carbon-fueled solid oxide fuel cells (CF-SOFCs) can electrochemically convert the chemical energy in carbon into electricity, which demonstrate both superior electrical efficiency and fuel utilisation compared to all other types of fuel cells. However, using solid carbon as the fuel of SOFCs also faces some challenges, the fluid mobility and reactive activity of carbon-based fuels are much lower than those of gaseous fuels. Therefore, the anode reaction kinetics plays a crucial role in determining the electrochemical performance of CF-SOFCs. Herein, the progress of various anodes in CF-SOFCs is reviewed from the perspective of material compositions, electrochemical performance and microstructures. Challenges faced in developing high performance anodes for CF-SOFCs are also discussed.
